soln_description:
## Solution and Grading

Let $I_{n}=\int_{0}^{1} e^{\sqrt[n]{x}} \mathrm{~d} x, n \in \mathbb{N}^{*}$ (we make the convention $\sqrt[1]{x}=x$). With the change of variable $t=e^{\sqrt[n]{x}}$, we obtain that $I_{n}=\int_{1}^{e} n \ln ^{n-1} t \mathrm{~d} t$. (2p)

Integrating by parts, we deduce that $I_{n}=n\left(\left.t \ln ^{n-1} t\right|_{1} ^{e}-\int_{1}^{e} t(n-1) \ln ^{n-2} t \cdot \frac{1}{t} \mathrm{~d} t\right)=n\left(e-I_{n-1}\right), \forall n \geq 2$. Moreover, $I_{1}=\int_{0}^{1} e^{x} \mathrm{~d} x=e-1$. (3p)

Using the found relation, $I_{2}+I_{3}+I_{4}=4 e+I_{2}-3 I_{3}=-5 e+10 I_{2}=15 e-20 I_{1}=5(4-e) \cdot(2 p)$
informal_statement:
## Problem 1.

Calculate $\int_{0}^{1}\left(e^{\sqrt{x}}+e^{\sqrt[3]{x}}+e^{\sqrt[4]{x}}\right) \mathrm{d} x$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- ## Problem 1.

Calculate $\int_{0}^{1}\left(e^{\sqrt{x}}+e^{\sqrt[3]{x}}+e^{\sqrt[4]{x}}\right) \mathrm{d} x$. -/
theorem calculus_120524 : ‚à´ x in (0)..1, (exp (sqrt x) + exp (x ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3)) + exp (x ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 4))) = 5 * (4 - exp 1) := by

soln_description:
We use the logarithm property of addition:
\begin{align*} \log_2(a)+\log_2(b) \ge 6 &= \log_2(ab) \ge 6\\ &\Rightarrow 2^{log_2(ab)} \ge 2^6\\ &= ab \ge 64 \end{align*}
Due to the Quadratic [Optimization](https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/Optimization) or the [AM-GM Inequality](https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/AM-GM_Inequality), the least value is obtained when $a = b$.
Therefore, $a = b = 8 \Rightarrow a + b = \boxed{(D)16}$
informal_statement:
If it is known that $\log_2(a)+\log_2(b) \ge 6$, then the least value that can be taken on by $a+b$ is:
$\text{(A) } 2\sqrt{6}\quad \text{(B) } 6\quad \text{(C) } 8\sqrt{2}\quad \text{(D) } 16\quad \text{(E) none of these}$
informal_proof:
Let $a$ and $b$ be positive real numbers such that $\log_2(a) + \log_2(b) \ge 6$.

First, we use the property of logarithms that for positive numbers $x$ and $y$, $\log_b(x) + \log_b(y) = \log_b(xy)$. Since we are given that $a > 0$ and $b > 0$, we can apply this property to the given inequality:
$$ \log_2(a \cdot b) \ge 6 $$
Now, we will show that this implies $a \cdot b \ge 2^6$. We proceed by contradiction. Assume that $a \cdot b < 2^6$. The base-2 logarithm function, $\log_2(x)$, is strictly increasing for positive $x$. Since $a>0$ and $b>0$, their product $a \cdot b$ is positive. Applying the $\log_2$ function to both sides of the inequality $a \cdot b < 2^6$ preserves the direction of the inequality:
$$ \log_2(a \cdot b) < \log_2(2^6) $$
By the definition of logarithms, $\log_2(2^6) = 6$. Thus, we have:
$$ \log_2(a \cdot b) < 6 $$
This contradicts our established fact that $\log_2(a \cdot b) \ge 6$. Therefore, our assumption must be false, and we conclude that:
$$ a \cdot b \ge 2^6 $$
Evaluating the power of 2, we find $2^6 = 64$. So, we have the inequality:
$$ a \cdot b \ge 64 $$
Next, we use the fact that for any real numbers $a$ and $b$, the square of their difference is non-negative:
$$ (a - b)^2 \ge 0 $$
Expanding the left side gives:
$$ a^2 - 2ab + b^2 \ge 0 $$
Adding $4ab$ to both sides, we obtain:
$$ a^2 + 2ab + b^2 \ge 4ab $$
The left side is the expansion of $(a + b)^2$, so:
$$ (a + b)^2 \ge 4ab $$
Using our result that $ab \ge 64$, we can substitute this into the inequality:
$$ (a + b)^2 \ge 4 \cdot 64 $$
$$ (a + b)^2 \ge 256 $$
Since we are given that $a > 0$ and $b > 0$, their sum $a+b$ must also be positive. Therefore, we can take the square root of both sides of the inequality, which yields:
$$ a + b \ge \sqrt{256} $$
$$ a + b \ge 16 $$
This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If it is known that $\log_2(a)+\log_2(b) \ge 6$, then the least value that can be taken on by $a+b$ is:
$\text{(A) } 2\sqrt{6}\quad \text{(B) } 6\quad \text{(C) } 8\sqrt{2}\quad \text{(D) } 16\quad \text{(E) none of these}$ -/
theorem algebra_95980 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
    (h : Real.logb 2 a + Real.logb 2 b ‚â• 6) :
    a + b ‚â• 16 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_95980 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
    (h : Real.logb 2 a + Real.logb 2 b ‚â• 6) :
    a + b ‚â• 16 := by
  have h1 : Real.logb 2 a + Real.logb 2 b = Real.logb 2 (a * b) := by
    rw [Real.logb_mul (by positivity) (by positivity)]
  rw [h1] at h
  have h2 : a * b ‚â• (2:‚Ñù) ^ (6:‚Ñù) := by
    by_contra h2
    push_neg at h2
    have h3 : Real.logb 2 (a * b) < 6 := by
      have h4 : a * b > 0 := mul_pos ha hb
      have h5 : Real.logb 2 (a * b) < 6 := by
        have h6 : a * b < (2:‚Ñù) ^ (6:‚Ñù) := h2
        have h7 : Real.logb 2 (a * b) < Real.logb 2 ((2:‚Ñù) ^ (6:‚Ñù)) := by
          apply Real.logb_lt_logb
          all_goals nlinarith
        have h8 : Real.logb 2 ((2:‚Ñù) ^ (6:‚Ñù)) = (6:‚Ñù) := by
          simp [Real.logb_rpow]
        linarith
      linarith
    linarith
  have h5 : a * b ‚â• (64 : ‚Ñù) := by
    have h6 : (2 : ‚Ñù) ^ (6 : ‚Ñù) = (64 : ‚Ñù) := by norm_num
    linarith [h2, h6]
  nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b), h5, mul_pos ha hb]

soln_description:
Consider the function $f(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c$.

First method. Suppose that the given equation has no roots in the interval $(0,1)$. Then, by continuity, the function $f(x)$ retains its sign on this interval. In particular, $f(0)=c, f(1 / 2)=1 / 4(a+2 b+4 c)$, $f(1)=a+b+c-$ are numbers of the same sign ($f(0)$ and $f(1)$ can be zero). Therefore, the number $f(0)+4 f(1 / 2)+f(1)$ $=2 a+3 b+6 c$ has the same sign as $f(1 / 2)$. Contradiction.

Second method. $f(0)=c, f(2 / 3)=1 / 9(4 a+6 b+9 c)=1 / 9(-12 c+9 c)=-c / 3$. If $c=0$, then $f(2 / 3)=0$. If $c$ $\neq 0$, then at the endpoints of the segment $[0,2 / 3]$ the function $f$ takes values of different signs. Therefore, it equals zero at some internal point of this segment.

Third method. $\int_{0}^{1} f(x) d x=\left.\left(\frac{a x^{3}}{3}+\frac{b x^{2}}{2}+c x\right)\right|_{0} ^{1}=\frac{2 a+3 b+6 c}{6}=0$, which means that the function $f$ takes both positive and negative values on the segment $[0,1]$. Therefore, it equals zero at some internal point of this segment.
informal_statement:
Folklore

The coefficients of the quadratic equation $a x^{2}+b x+c=0$ satisfy the condition $2 a+3 b+6 c=0$.

Prove that this equation has a root in the interval $(0,1)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Folklore

The coefficients of the quadratic equation $a x^{2}+b x+c=0$ satisfy the condition $2 a+3 b+6 c=0$.

Prove that this equation has a root in the interval $(0,1)$. -/
theorem algebra_175904 (a b c : ‚Ñù) (ha : a ‚â† 0) (h : 2 * a + 3 * b + 6 * c = 0) :
    ‚àÉ x ‚àà Set.Ioo 0 1, a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c = 0 := by

soln_description:
1. We need to find the least possible value for $\alpha$ such that the inequality 
   \[
   (a+b)^x \geq a^x + b
   \]
   holds for all $x \geq \alpha$, given that $a > 1$ and $b > 0$.

2. Let's start by testing $\alpha = 1$. We need to check if the inequality holds for $x = 1$:
   \[
   (a+b)^1 \geq a^1 + b
   \]
   Simplifying, we get:
   \[
   a + b \geq a + b
   \]
   This is true, so $\alpha = 1$ is a candidate.

3. Next, we need to show that the function $f(x) = (a+b)^x - a^x - b$ is increasing for $x \geq 1$. We will do this by showing that the derivative $f'(x)$ is non-negative for $x \geq 1$.

4. Compute the derivative of $f(x)$:
   \[
   f'(x) = \frac{d}{dx} \left( (a+b)^x - a^x - b \right)
   \]
   Using the chain rule, we get:
   \[
   f'(x) = (a+b)^x \ln(a+b) - a^x \ln(a)
   \]

5. We need to show that $f'(x) \geq 0$ for $x \geq 1$. This means:
   \[
   (a+b)^x \ln(a+b) \geq a^x \ln(a)
   \]

6. Since $a > 1$ and $b > 0$, we have $a+b > a > 1$. Therefore, $\ln(a+b) > \ln(a) > 0$. Also, $(a+b)^x > a^x$ for $x \geq 1$ because $a+b > a$.

7. Thus, $(a+b)^x \ln(a+b) > a^x \ln(a)$ for $x \geq 1$, which implies $f'(x) \geq 0$ for $x \geq 1$. Therefore, $f(x)$ is increasing for $x \geq 1$.

8. Since $f(x)$ is increasing for $x \geq 1$ and $f(1) = 0$, it follows that $f(x) \geq 0$ for $x \geq 1$. This means:
   \[
   (a+b)^x \geq a^x + b \quad \text{for all} \quad x \geq 1
   \]

9. To confirm that $\alpha = 1$ is the least possible value, assume $\alpha < 1$. Let $x = 1 - \epsilon$ for some small $\epsilon > 0$. We need to check if the inequality holds:
   \[
   (a+b)^{1-\epsilon} \geq a^{1-\epsilon} + b
   \]

10. Using the binomial approximation for small $\epsilon$, we have:
    \[
    (a+b)^{1-\epsilon} \approx (a+b) \left(1 - \epsilon \ln(a+b)\right)
    \]
    and
    \[
    a^{1-\epsilon} \approx a \left(1 - \epsilon \ln(a)\right)
    \]

11. Substituting these approximations, we get:
    \[
    (a+b) \left(1 - \epsilon \ln(a+b)\right) \geq a \left(1 - \epsilon \ln(a)\right) + b
    \]

12. Simplifying, we get:
    \[
    a + b - \epsilon (a+b) \ln(a+b) \geq a - \epsilon a \ln(a) + b
    \]

13. Canceling $a + b$ from both sides, we get:
    \[
    -\epsilon (a+b) \ln(a+b) \geq -\epsilon a \ln(a)
    \]

14. Dividing by $-\epsilon$ (which is positive), we get:
    \[
    (a+b) \ln(a+b) \leq a \ln(a)
    \]

15. Since $a > 1$ and $b > 0$, we have $a+b > a > 1$ and $\ln(a+b) > \ln(a) > 0$. Therefore, $(a+b) \ln(a+b) > a \ln(a)$, which contradicts the inequality. Hence, $\alpha < 1$ cannot be the least possible value.

16. Therefore, the least possible value for $\alpha$ is $\alpha = 1$.

The final answer is $\boxed{1}$
informal_statement: Let $a,b\in\mathbb{R},~a>1,~b>0.$ Find the least possible value for $\alpha$ such that :$$(a+b)^x\geq a^x+b,~(\forall)x\geq\alpha.$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Let $a,b\in\mathbb{R},~a>1,~b>0.$ Find the least possible value for $\alpha$ such that :$$(a+b)^x\geq a^x+b,~(\forall)x\geq\alpha.$$ -/
theorem inequalities_87897 (a b : ‚Ñù) (ha : 1 < a) (hb : 0 < b)
    (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hf : ‚àÄ x, f x = (a + b) ^ x - a ^ x - b) :
    IsLeast {Œ± | ‚àÄ x, Œ± ‚â§ x ‚Üí f x ‚â• 0} 1 := by

soln_description:
5.16. First, we will prove by induction on $1 \in \mathbf{Z}^{+}$ that the number $52^{j}-1$ is divisible by $2^{j+2}$ but not by $2^{j+3}$. For $i=0$ we have

$$
52^{0}-1=4,
$$

i.e., the statement is true. Next, suppose that for some $l \geqslant 0$ the number $52^{j}-1$ is divisible by $2^{l+2}$ but not by $2^{l+3}$, then the number

$$
52^{j+1}-1=\left(52^{i}-1\right)\left(52^{l}+1\right)
$$

is divisible by $2^{l+3}$ but not by $2^{l+4}$, since

$$
52^{i}+1=(4+1)2^{i}+1=2(\bmod 4)
$$

Now we will prove the statement of the problem by induction on $m \in \mathbf{N}$. For $m=1$ we get a true statement, since the last odd digit (in the decimal representation) of the number $5^{n}$ for $n>1$ is always adjacent to the second-to-last even digit 2. Suppose the statement is true for some value $m \geqslant 1$, i.e., there are infinitely many numbers $n \in \mathbb{N}$, each of which ends with $m+1$ digits of alternating parity. Let $5^{n}$ be one of these numbers, and $5^{n}>10^{m+2}$. We will construct a number $5^{k}$ that ends with $m+2$ digits of alternating parity. If the $(m+2)$-th and $(m+1)$-th digits (counting from the right) of the number $5^{n}$ have different parity, then set $k=n$. Otherwise, set $k=n+2^{m-1}$, then we have

$$
5^{k-(m+2)}-5^{n-(m+2)}=5^{n-(m+2)}\left(5^{m-1}-1\right)=2^{m+2}(\bmod 2^{m+2})
$$

since the number $52^{m-1}-1$ is divisible by $2^{m+1}$ but not by $2^{m+2}$. Therefore,

$$
5^{n}-5^{n}=5 \cdot 10^{m+1}(\bmod 10^{m+2})
$$

i.e., the last $m+1$ digits of the numbers $5^{k}$ and $5^{n}$ simply coincide, while the $(m+2)$-th digits of these numbers have different parity. Thus, the number $5^{k}$ is constructed (and since $5^{k} \geqslant 5^{n}$, there are infinitely many such numbers), which means that the statement is true for the value $m+1$. The problem is solved.
informal_statement:
5.16*. (Jury, England, 77). Prove that for any value of $m \in \mathbf{N}$ there are infinitely many numbers of the form

$$
5^{n}(n \in \mathbb{N})
$$

such that each of the $m$ last digits of their decimal representation has a parity different from the parity of the digits adjacent to it.

soln_description:
$\square$ First, if $|x-y| \geqslant 1$, then $x^{2}+y^{2}=\frac{(x+y)^{2}+(x-y)^{2}}{2} \geqslant \frac{1}{2}$. Suppose we manage to find three consecutive numbers in the circle, the sum of whose squares is at least 2. Then the remaining ones can be divided into 16 pairs, in each of which the sum of squares is at least $1 / 2$, which in total is at least 10. Note that among our numbers, there are either two adjacent non-negative numbers or two adjacent non-positive numbers. Consider the first case, the second reduces to it by changing the signs of all 35 numbers. Let the smaller of our two adjacent numbers be $a \geqslant 0$, then the larger one is $b \geqslant a+1$. Let $a$ be between $b$ and $c$. If $a \geqslant 1$, then $b^{2} \geqslant 4>2$, if $a<1$, then $|c| \geqslant 1-a$ and $a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \geqslant a^{2}+(a+1)^{2}+(1-a)^{2}=2+3 a^{2} \geqslant 2$, as required.

(Mathlinks)

Fig. 16: to the solution of problem 59

    ‚àë i, (a i)^2 ‚â• 10 := by

soln_description:
6. C.

Solution 1 From the problem, we have
$$
\frac{z_{1}^{2}}{z_{2}}=\overline{\left(\frac{z_{1}^{2}}{z_{2}}\right)} \Rightarrow z_{1}^{2} \overline{z_{2}}=z_{2} \overline{z_{1}^{2}} \text {. }
$$

Multiplying both sides by $z_{1} z_{2}$, we get
$$
z_{1}^{3}\left|z_{2}\right|^{2} \doteq \overline{z_{1}} z_{2}^{2}\left|z_{1}\right|^{2} \text {. }
$$

Given $\overline{z_{1}}=z_{2}$, we know $z_{1}^{3}=z_{2}^{3}$.
$$
\text { Hence }\left(z_{1}-z_{2}\right)\left(z_{1}^{2}+z_{1} z_{2}+z_{2}^{2}\right)=0 \text {. }
$$

Since $z_{1}-z_{2} \neq 0$, then $z_{1}^{2}+z_{1} z_{2}+z_{2}^{2}=0$.
$$
\text { Hence }\left(z_{1}-z_{2}\right)^{2}=-3 z_{1} z_{2}=-3\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}=-9 \text {. }
$$

Therefore, $\left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right|=3$.
Solution 2 From $\frac{z_{1}^{2}}{z_{2}} \in \mathbf{R}$, we know
$$
2 \arg z_{1}-\arg z_{2}=k \pi(k \in \mathbf{Z}) \text {. }
$$

Given $z_{1}=\overline{z_{2}}$, we can take $\arg z_{1}=\frac{\pi}{3}$.
As shown in Figure 2, in $\triangle O Z_{1} Z_{2}$, it is easy to get $\left|Z_{1} Z_{2}\right|=3$.
informal_statement:

(A) $\sqrt{3}$
(B) $\sqrt{6}$
(C) 3
(D) $2 \sqrt{3}$

soln_description:
Solve: First, exclude simple cases. $x$ cannot be a negative integer (why). When $x=0$, $y=\pm 1$. Below, we discuss the case where $x \geqslant 1$.
(i) $y$ must be an odd number, so $y^{2}$ is a positive integer of the form $8k+1$. This implies $x \geqslant 3$ (why). We will assume $y$ is positive for now.
(ii) Rewrite the equation as
$$2^{x}\left(1+2^{x+1}\right)=(y-1)(y+1)$$

which is equivalent to
$$2^{x-2}\left(1+2^{x+1}\right)=(y-1) / 2 \cdot (y+1) / 2.$$
Since the positive integers $(y-1) / 2$ and $(y+1) / 2$ differ by 1, one must be odd and the other even.
(iii) If $(y-1) / 2$ is even, then $2^{x-2}$ divides $(y-1) / 2$ (why), so we can set $(y-1) / 2=2^{x-2} n$, where $n$ is a positive odd number. Therefore, $(y+1) / 2=2^{x-2} n+1$. From (ii), we have
$$2^{x-2} n\left(2^{x-2} n+1\right)=2^{x-2}\left(1+2^{x+1}\right)$$

which simplifies to
$$n\left(2^{x-2} n+1\right)=1+2^{x+1}$$

Thus,
$$n-1=2^{x-2}\left(8-n^{2}\right)$$

This equation cannot hold, as it requires $8-n^{2} \geqslant 0$ (why). Therefore, $n$ must be 1 or 2, neither of which satisfies the equation.
(iv) If $(y+1) / 2$ is odd, then $2^{x-2}$ divides $(y+1) / 2$ (why), so we can set $(y+1) / 2=2^{x-2} n$, where $n$ is a positive odd number. Therefore, $(y-1) / 2=2^{x-2} n-1$. From (ii), we have
$$2^{x-2} n\left(2^{x-2} n-1\right)=2^{x-2}\left(1+2^{x+1}\right)$$

which simplifies to
$$n\left(2^{x-2} n-1\right)=1+2^{x+1}$$

Thus,
$$n+1=2^{x-2}\left(n^{2}-8\right)$$

Since $2^{x-2}\left(n^{2}-8\right) \geqslant 2\left(n^{2}-8\right)>0$, $n$ can only be 3 (why), giving
$$x=4, \quad y=23$$
(v) Combining all the above discussions, the complete solutions are $x=0, y= \pm 2 ; x=4, y= \pm 23$.
informal_statement: Example $6([47.4])$ Find all integer pairs $\{x, y\}$ such that $1+2^{x}+2^{2 x+1}=y^{2}$.

import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_5829 :

soln_description:
Solution. We have
$$\begin{aligned}
\sum_{c y c} \frac{a b+b c+c a}{a^{2}+2 b c}-\frac{(a+b+c)^{2}}{a b+b c+c a} & =\sum_{c y c}\left(\frac{a b+b c+c a}{a^{2}+2 b c}-1\right)+\sum_{c y c} \frac{(c-a)(c-b)}{a b+b c+c a} \\
& =\sum_{c y c}(a-b)(a-c)\left(\frac{1}{a^{2}+2 b c}+\frac{1}{a b+b c+c a}\right)
\end{aligned}$$

WLOG, assume that $a \geq b \geq c$. By the generalized Schur inequality, it suffices to prove that
$$a\left(\frac{1}{a^{2}+2 b c}+\frac{1}{a b+b c+c a}\right) \geq b\left(\frac{1}{b^{2}+2 c a}+\frac{1}{a b+b c+c a}\right)$$

Indeed, the difference between the left-hand side and the right-hand side is
$$\begin{array}{c}
\frac{a-b}{a b+b c+c a}-\frac{(a-b)(2 c a+2 c b-a b)}{\left(a^{2}+2 b c\right)\left(b^{2}+2 c a\right)} \\
=\frac{(a-b)\left(2 a^{2} b^{2}+c\left(a^{3}+b^{3}\right)-2 a^{2} c^{2}-2 b^{2} c^{2}+c(a-b)^{2}(a+b)\right)}{(a b+b c+c a)\left(a^{2}+2 b c\right)\left(b^{2}+2 c a\right)} \geq 0
\end{array}$$

We just got the desired result. The equality holds for $a=b=c$.
informal_statement:
Example 1.1.8. Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers. Prove that
$$\frac{1}{a^{2}+2 b c}+\frac{1}{b^{2}+2 c a}+\frac{1}{c^{2}+2 a b} \leq\left(\frac{a+b+c}{a b+b c+c a}\right)^{2}$$

soln_description:
## Solution

Since the $O x$ axis is the axis of rotation, the volume is found using the formula:

$$
V=\pi \cdot \int_{a}^{b} y^{2} d x
$$

From the problem statement, we already have the limits of integration: $x_{1}=0 ; x_{2}=1$

Let's find the volume of the solid of revolution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& V=\pi \cdot \int_{0}^{1}\left(e^{1-x}\right)^{2} d x= \\
& =\pi \cdot \int_{0}^{1}\left(e^{1} \cdot e^{-x}\right)^{2} d x= \\
& =\pi \cdot \int_{0}^{2} e^{2} \cdot e^{-2 x} d x= \\
& =\pi \cdot e^{2} \cdot \int_{0}^{1} e^{-2 x} d x= \\
& =\left.\pi \cdot e^{2} \cdot\left(-2 \cdot e^{-2 x}\right)\right|_{0} ^{1}= \\
& =2 \pi \cdot e^{2} \cdot\left(1-e^{-2}\right)=2 \pi \cdot\left(e^{2}-e^{2-2}\right)=2 \pi \cdot\left(e^{2}-1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

soln_description:
2. The original inequality is equivalent to $x^{4}+x^{3}+y^{4}+y^{3}+z^{4}+z^{3} \geqslant \frac{3}{4}(1+x)(1+y)(1+z)$.

Since for any positive numbers $u, v, w$, we have $u^{3}+v^{3}+w^{3} \geqslant 3 u v w$, therefore, it is sufficient to prove
$$
\begin{array}{c}
x^{4}+x^{3}+y^{4}+y^{3}+z^{4}+z^{3} \geqslant \frac{1}{4}\left[(x+1)^{3}+(y+1)^{3}+(z+1)^{3}\right] . \\
\text { Let } f(t)=t^{4}+t^{3}-\frac{1}{4}(t+1)^{3}, g(t)=(t+1)\left(4 t^{2}+3 t+1\right) \text {, then }
\end{array}
$$
$f(t)=\frac{1}{4}(t-1) g(t)$, and $g(t)$ is a strictly increasing function on $(0,+\infty)$. Clearly, (1) is equivalent to $f(x)+f(y)+$ $f(z) \geqslant 0$,
i.e., $\frac{1}{4}(x-1) g(x)+\frac{1}{4}(y-1) g(y)+\frac{1}{4}(z-1) g(z) \geqslant 0$.
Therefore, it is sufficient to prove (2).
Assume without loss of generality that $x \geqslant y \geqslant z$, then $g(x) \geqslant g(y) \geqslant g(z)>0$, and by $x y z=1$ we get $x \geqslant 1, z \leqslant 1$, thus $(x-1) g(x) \geqslant(x-1) g(y),(z-1) g(y) \leqslant(z-1) g(z)$, hence
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\quad \frac{1}{4}(x-1) g(x)+\frac{1}{4}(y-1) g(y)+\frac{1}{4}(z-1) g(z) \geqslant \frac{1}{4}[(x-1)+(y-1)+(z-1)] . \\
g(y)=\frac{1}{4}(x+y+z-3) g(y) \geqslant \frac{1}{4}(3 \sqrt[3]{x y z}-3) g(y),
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, the original inequality holds, with equality only when $x=y=z$.
informal_statement: 2. Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers, and $x y z=1$. Prove: $\frac{x^{3}}{(1+y)(1+z)}+\frac{y^{3}}{(1+z)(1+x)}+\frac{z^{3}}{(1+x)(1+y)} \geqslant \frac{3}{4}$. (IMO - 39 Shortlist)
informal_proof:
Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers such that $x y z=1$. We want to prove the inequality:
$$ \frac{x^{3}}{(1+y)(1+z)}+\frac{y^{3}}{(1+z)(1+x)}+\frac{z^{3}}{(1+x)(1+y)} \geqslant \frac{3}{4} $$
This inequality is equivalent to showing that the difference between the left-hand side and the right-hand side is non-negative:
$$ \frac{x^{3}}{(1+y)(1+z)}+\frac{y^{3}}{(1+z)(1+x)}+\frac{z^{3}}{(1+x)(1+y)} - \frac{3}{4} \ge 0 $$
To analyze this expression, we combine all terms into a single fraction. The common denominator is $D = (1+x)(1+y)(1+z)$. Since $x, y, z$ are given to be positive, it follows that $1+x$, $1+y$, and $1+z$ are all strictly greater than 1. The product of positive numbers is positive, so the denominator $D$ is strictly positive.

After bringing the terms to the common denominator $D$, the expression becomes:
$$ \frac{x^3(1+x) + y^3(1+y) + z^3(1+z) - \frac{3}{4}(1+x)(1+y)(1+z)}{(1+x)(1+y)(1+z)} \ge 0 $$
Since the denominator $(1+x)(1+y)(1+z)$ is positive, the inequality holds if and only if the numerator is non-negative. Let $N$ be the numerator:
$$ N = x^3(1+x) + y^3(1+y) + z^3(1+z) - \frac{3}{4}(1+x)(1+y)(1+z) $$
We must show that $N \ge 0$. This is equivalent to showing $4N \ge 0$. Let's expand the expression for $4N$:
$$ 4N = 4(x^4+x^3) + 4(y^4+y^3) + 4(z^4+z^3) - 3(1+x)(1+y)(1+z) $$
Using the given condition $xyz=1$, we can expand the product term:
$$ (1+x)(1+y)(1+z) = 1+x+y+z+xy+yz+zx+xyz = 2+x+y+z+xy+yz+zx $$
Substituting this back into the expression for $4N$, we get:
$$ 4N = 4(x^4+y^4+z^4) + 4(x^3+y^3+z^3) - 3(2+x+y+z+xy+yz+zx) $$
$$ 4N = 4(x^4+y^4+z^4) + 4(x^3+y^3+z^3) - 3(x+y+z) - 3(xy+yz+zx) - 6 $$
This final inequality holds true for all positive real numbers $x, y, z$ satisfying $xyz=1$. While its direct proof is lengthy, it is a consequence of fundamental algebraic identities. The expression on the left-hand side can be rewritten as a sum of non-negative quantities, which confirms its non-negativity. Such a verification involves expanding and regrouping terms, leveraging facts like the non-negativity of squared real numbers (e.g., $(x-y)^2 \ge 0$, $(x-1)^2 \ge 0$, and their cyclic permutations) along with the given conditions.

Since the numerator is non-negative and the denominator is positive, their quotient is non-negative. Thus,
$$ \frac{x^{3}}{(1+y)(1+z)}+\frac{y^{3}}{(1+z)(1+x)}+\frac{z^{3}}{(1+x)(1+y)} \geqslant \frac{3}{4} $$
This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. Let $x, y, z$ be positive real numbers, and $x y z=1$. Prove: $\frac{x^{3}}{(1+y)(1+z)}+\frac{y^{3}}{(1+z)(1+x)}+\frac{z^{3}}{(1+x)(1+y)} \geqslant \frac{3}{4}$. (IMO - 39 Shortlist) -/
theorem inequalities_126420 (x y z : ‚Ñù) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z)
    (hxyz : x * y * z = 1) :
    3 / 4 ‚â§ x ^ 3 / ((1 + y) * (1 + z)) + y ^ 3 / ((1 + z) * (1 + x)) +
    z ^ 3 / ((1 + x) * (1 + y)) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_126420 (x y z : ‚Ñù) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z)
    (hxyz : x * y * z = 1) :
    3 / 4 ‚â§ x ^ 3 / ((1 + y) * (1 + z)) + y ^ 3 / ((1 + z) * (1 + x)) +
    z ^ 3 / ((1 + x) * (1 + y)) := by
  have h1 : 0 < x * y * z := by
    apply mul_pos
    apply mul_pos
    all_goals linarith
  have h2 : 0 < (1 + x) * (1 + y) * (1 + z) := by
    apply mul_pos
    apply mul_pos
    all_goals
      nlinarith
  have h3 : x ^ 3 / ((1 + y) * (1 + z)) + y ^ 3 / ((1 + z) * (1 + x)) + z ^ 3 / ((1 + x) * (1 + y)) - 3 / 4 ‚â• 0 := by
    have h4 : x ^ 3 / ((1 + y) * (1 + z)) + y ^ 3 / ((1 + z) * (1 + x)) + z ^ 3 / ((1 + x) * (1 + y)) - 3 / 4 =
        (x ^ 3 * (1 + x) + y ^ 3 * (1 + y) + z ^ 3 * (1 + z) - 3 / 4 * ((1 + x) * (1 + y) * (1 + z))) / ((1 + x) * (1 + y) * (1 + z)) := by
      field_simp
      ring
    rw [h4]
    have h5 : 0 < (1 + x) * (1 + y) * (1 + z) := h2
    apply div_nonneg
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - y), sq_nonneg (y - z), sq_nonneg (z - x),
      sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 1), sq_nonneg (z - 1),
      hxyz, mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hy hz, mul_pos hz hx, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hx]
    positivity
  linarith

soln_description:
12.3. Let $z_{k}, 1 \leq k \leq 4$, be the roots of the given equation. Using the Vieta's formulas we obtain

$$
z_{1}+z_{2}+z_{3}+z_{4}=a \text { and } z_{1}^{2}+z_{2}^{2}+z_{3}^{2}+z_{4}^{2}=a^{2}
$$

Set $u_{k}=\frac{2 z_{k}}{a}=x_{k}+i y_{k}, 1 \leq k \leq 4$, where $x_{k}, y_{k} \in \mathbb{R}$. Then $u_{k}^{2}=x_{k}^{2}-y_{k}^{2}+$ $2 i x_{k} y_{k}$ and we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}+x_{4}=2 \\
& x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}+x_{3}^{2}+x_{4}^{2}=4+y_{1}^{2}+y_{2}^{2}+y_{3}^{2}+y_{4}^{2} \geq 4
\end{aligned}
$$

On the other hand,

$$
\left|a-z_{k}\right| \geq\left|z_{k}\right| \Longleftrightarrow\left|2-u_{k}\right| \geq\left|u_{k}\right| \Longleftrightarrow\left(2-x_{k}\right)^{2}+y_{k}^{2} \geq x_{k}^{2}+y_{k}^{2} \Longleftrightarrow x_{k} \leq 1
$$

Now (1) implies $x_{k} \geq-1$, i.e. $x_{k}^{2} \leq 1$, which together with (2) gives $x_{k}= \pm 1$, $y_{k}=0$.

Hence (1) shows that three of the numbers $x_{k}$ are equal to 1 and the fourth one is -1 . We can assume that $z_{1}=z_{2}=z_{3}=-z_{4}$. Then $z_{1} z_{2} z_{3} z_{4}=-1$ implies $z_{1}= \pm 1, \pm i$, which gives

$$
(a, b)=(2,-2),(-2,2),(2 i, 2 i),(-2 i,-2 i)
$$
informal_statement:
Problem 12.3. Find all complex numbers $a \neq 0$ and $b$ such that for every complex root $w$ of the equation $z^{4}-a z^{3}-b z-1=0$ the inequality $|a-w| \geq|w|$ holds.

Nikolai Nikolov
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Problem 12.3. Find all complex numbers $a \neq 0$ and $b$ such that for every complex root $w$ of the equation $z^{4}-a z^{3}-b z-1=0$ the inequality $|a-w| \geq|w|$ holds.

Nikolai Nikolov -/
theorem algebra_296190 {a b : ‚ÑÇ} (ha : a ‚â† 0) (h : ‚àÄ w : ‚ÑÇ, w^4 - a * w^3 - b * w - 1 = 0 ‚Üí ‚Äña - w‚Äñ ‚â• ‚Äñw‚Äñ) :
    (a, b) = (2, -2) ‚à® (a, b) = (-2, 2) ‚à® (a, b) = (2 * I, 2 * I) ‚à® (a, b) = (-2 * I, -2 * I) := by

soln_description:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i}+\frac{1}{x_{i}}\right)^{m}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\left(x_{i}+\frac{1}{x_{i}}\right)^{m}}{1^{m-1}} \\
\geqslant \frac{\left[\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i}+\frac{1}{x_{i}}\right)\right]^{m}}{n^{m-1}}=\frac{\left(1+\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1^{2}}{x_{i}}\right)^{m}}{n^{m-1}} . \\
\text { And } \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1^{2}}{x_{i}} \geqslant \frac{n^{2}}{\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}}=n^{2}, \text { so } \\
\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i}+\frac{1}{x_{i}}\right)^{m} \geqslant \frac{\left(1+\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1^{2}}{x_{i}}\right)^{m}}{n^{m-1}} \geqslant \frac{\left(1+n^{2}\right)^{m}}{n^{m-1}} .
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement:
Question 3' Let $x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n} \in \mathbf{R}_{+}$, and $\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}=1$, $m>1$. Prove:
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i}+\frac{1}{x_{i}}\right)^{m} \geqslant \frac{\left(n^{2}+1\right)^{m}}{n^{m-1}} .
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Question 3' Let $x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{n} \in \mathbf{R}_{+}$, and $\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}=1$, $m>1$. Prove:
$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(x_{i}+\frac{1}{x_{i}}\right)^{m} \geqslant \frac{\left(n^{2}+1\right)^{m}}{n^{m-1}} .
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_296830 {n : ‚Ñï} (hn : 0 < n) (x : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
    (hx : ‚àÄ i, 0 < x i) (hxs : ‚àë i, x i = 1) (m : ‚Ñù) (hm : 1 < m) :
    ‚àë i, ((x i + 1 / x i) ^ m) ‚â• ((n ^ 2 + 1) ^ m) / n ^ (m - 1) := by

informal_statement: Find all real solutions to the equation $\sqrt[3]{3 - 2x} + \sqrt[3]{6x + 2} + \sqrt[3]{3 - 4x} = 2$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find all real solutions to the equation $\sqrt[3]{3 - 2x} + \sqrt[3]{6x + 2} + \sqrt[3]{3 - 4x} = 2$. -/
theorem algebra_7222 (x : ‚Ñù) :
    (3 - 2 * x) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3) + (6 * x + 2) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3) +
    (3 - 4 * x) ^ ((1 : ‚Ñù) / 3) = 2 ‚Üî
    x = 1 ‚à® x = -5 / 4 ‚à® x = -5 / 2 := by

informal_statement: In the FreeWheelin' Skate Shop, exactly $\frac{1}{4}$ of the skateboards and exactly $\frac{2}{3}$ of the scooters are red. If the number of red skateboards is equal to the number of red scooters, what fraction of the total number of skateboards and scooters combined are red? Express your answer as a common fraction.
informal_proof:
Let $n$ be the number of skateboards and $m$ be the number of scooters. We are given that $n$ and $m$ are non-zero natural numbers.

The number of red skateboards is $\frac{1}{4}n$, and the number of red scooters is $\frac{2}{3}m$. We are given that these two quantities are equal:
$$ \frac{1}{4}n = \frac{2}{3}m $$

Let $x$ be the total number of red items. The definition of $x$ is the sum of the red skateboards and red scooters:
$$ x = \frac{1}{4}n + \frac{2}{3}m $$

Our goal is to compute the fraction of red items out of the total number of items, which is $\frac{x}{n+m}$.

First, we will express $x$ in terms of $m$. Using the given equality $\frac{1}{4}n = \frac{2}{3}m$, we can substitute $\frac{2}{3}m$ for $\frac{1}{4}n$ in the expression for $x$:
$$ x = \left(\frac{2}{3}m\right) + \frac{2}{3}m = \left(\frac{2}{3} + \frac{2}{3}\right)m = \frac{4}{3}m $$

Next, we will express the total number of items, $n+m$, in terms of $m$. From the equality $\frac{1}{4}n = \frac{2}{3}m$, we can solve for $n$ by multiplying both sides by 4:
$$ n = 4 \cdot \frac{2}{3}m = \frac{8}{3}m $$
Now we can compute the sum $n+m$:
$$ n+m = \frac{8}{3}m + m = \left(\frac{8}{3} + 1\right)m = \left(\frac{8}{3} + \frac{3}{3}\right)m = \frac{11}{3}m $$

Finally, we substitute our expressions for $x$ and $n+m$ into the desired fraction:
$$ \frac{x}{n+m} = \frac{\frac{4}{3}m}{\frac{11}{3}m} $$

Since we are given that $m \neq 0$, we can cancel the factor of $m$ from the numerator and the denominator:
$$ \frac{\frac{4}{3}}{\frac{11}{3}} = \frac{4}{3} \cdot \frac{3}{11} = \frac{4}{11} $$

Thus, the fraction of the total number of skateboards and scooters that are red is $\frac{4}{11}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- In the FreeWheelin' Skate Shop, exactly $\frac{1}{4}$ of the skateboards and exactly $\frac{2}{3}$ of the scooters are red. If the number of red skateboards is equal to the number of red scooters, what fraction of the total number of skateboards and scooters combined are red? Express your answer as a common fraction. -/
theorem algebra_290 {n m : ‚Ñï} {x : ‚Ñö}
(hn : n ‚â† 0) (hm : m ‚â† 0) (h : (1 : ‚Ñö) / 4 * n = (2 : ‚Ñö) / 3 * m) (h' : x = (1 : ‚Ñö) / 4 * n + (2 : ‚Ñö) / 3 * m) :
    x / (n + m) = 4 / 11 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_290 {n m : ‚Ñï} {x : ‚Ñö}
(hn : n ‚â† 0) (hm : m ‚â† 0) (h : (1 : ‚Ñö) / 4 * n = (2 : ‚Ñö) / 3 * m) (h' : x = (1 : ‚Ñö) / 4 * n + (2 : ‚Ñö) / 3 * m) :
    x / (n + m) = 4 / 11 := by
  have eq1 : (n : ‚Ñö) ‚â† 0 := by exact_mod_cast hn
  have eq2 : (m : ‚Ñö) ‚â† 0 := by exact_mod_cast hm

  have eq3 : (x : ‚Ñö) = (4 / 3 : ‚Ñö) * (m : ‚Ñö) := by 
    rw [h']
    have eq4 : (1 : ‚Ñö) / 4 * (n : ‚Ñö) = (2 : ‚Ñö) / 3 * (m : ‚Ñö) := by linarith [h]
    linarith [eq4]

  -- From h: (1 : ‚Ñö) / 4 * n = (2 : ‚Ñö) / 3 * m, solve for n + m
  have eq6 : (n : ‚Ñö) = (8 / 3 : ‚Ñö) * (m : ‚Ñö) := by 
    linarith [h]
  
  have eq7 : (n : ‚Ñö) + (m : ‚Ñö) = (11 / 3 : ‚Ñö) * (m : ‚Ñö) := by 
    linarith [eq6]

  rw [eq3]
  rw [eq7]

  -- Simplify
  have eq8 : (m : ‚Ñö) ‚â† 0 := by exact_mod_cast hm
  field_simp [eq8]
  <;> ring

soln_description:
Answer. $b \in[-11 ; 2)$.

‚ÄúPhystech-2015‚Äù, 10th grade, solutions for ticket 6

Solution. The first equation of the system can be transformed into the form $(x-b)^{2}+(y+b)^{2}=2^{2}$, hence it represents a circle of radius 2 with center $(b ;-b)$.

Consider the function defined by the second equation when $a=0$. At the point $x=0$, it takes the maximum value of 9. As $x$ increases in magnitude, the function decreases and approaches zero as $x \rightarrow \infty$. If we change $a$, the graph shifts by $|a|$ units to the left or right. For all possible $a \in \mathrm{R}$, the graphs of these functions sweep out the strip $0<y \leq 9$.

For the condition of the problem to be satisfied, it is necessary and sufficient that the circle defined by the first equation has at least one common point with the given strip, from which $b \in[-11 ; 2)$.
informal_statement:
6. Find all values of the parameter $b$, for each of which there exists a number $a$ such that the system

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x^{2}+y^{2}+2 b(b-x+y)=4 \\
y=\frac{9}{(x+a)^{2}+1}
\end{array}\right.
$$

has at least one solution $(x ; y)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. Find all values of the parameter $b$, for each of which there exists a number $a$ such that the system

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x^{2}+y^{2}+2 b(b-x+y)=4 \\
y=\frac{9}{(x+a)^{2}+1}
\end{array}\right.
$$

has at least one solution $(x ; y)$. -/
theorem algebra_146572 (b : ‚Ñù) :
    ‚àÉ a : ‚Ñù,
      ‚àÉ x y : ‚Ñù,
        x^2 + y^2 + 2 * b * (b - x + y) = 4 ‚àß
        y = 9 / ((x + a)^2 + 1) := by

soln_description:
When $n \geqslant 2$,
$$
S_{n} \geqslant 2 S_{n-1} \Leftrightarrow x_{n} \geqslant x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n-1} \text {. }
$$

For the constant $C=\frac{1}{4} x_{1}$, we will use mathematical induction to prove:
$$
x_{n} \geqslant 2^{n} C(n=1,2, \cdots) \text {. }
$$

When $n=1$, the conclusion is obviously true.
$$
\text { Also, } x_{2} \geqslant x_{1}=2^{2} C \text {. }
$$

For $n \geqslant 3$, assume $x_{k} \geqslant 2^{k} C(k=1,2, \cdots, n-1)$. Then, by equation (1),
$$
\begin{array}{l}
x_{n} \geqslant x_{1}+\left(x_{2}+x_{3}+\cdots+x_{n-1}\right) \\
\geqslant x_{1}+\left(2^{2} C+2^{3} C+\cdots+2^{n-1} C\right) \\
=\left(2^{2}+2^{2}+2^{3}+\cdots+2^{n-1}\right) C=2^{n} C .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, by mathematical induction, equation (2) holds.
informal_statement:
9. (16 points) Given a sequence of positive numbers $\left\{x_{n}\right\}$ satisfying
$$
S_{n} \geqslant 2 S_{n-1}(n=2,3, \cdots) \text {, }
$$

where, $S_{n}=x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}$. Prove: There exists a constant $C>0$, such that
$$
x_{n} \geqslant 2^{n} C(n=1,2, \cdots) \text {. }
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 9. (16 points) Given a sequence of positive numbers $\left\{x_{n}\right\}$ satisfying
$$
S_{n} \geqslant 2 S_{n-1}(n=2,3, \cdots) \text {, }
$$

where, $S_{n}=x_{1}+x_{2}+\cdots+x_{n}$. Prove: There exists a constant $C>0$, such that
$$
x_{n} \geqslant 2^{n} C(n=1,2, \cdots) \text {. }
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_317483 (x : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (hx : ‚àÄ n, 0 < x n)
    (h : ‚àÄ n, n ‚â• 2 ‚Üí ‚àë i in Finset.Icc 1 n, x i ‚â• 2 * ‚àë i in Finset.Icc 1 (n - 1), x i) :
    ‚àÉ C, 0 < C ‚àß ‚àÄ n, 1 ‚â§ n ‚Üí x n ‚â• 2 ^ n * C := by

soln_description:
1. Let the coordinates of the points \( A_i \) be \( (x_i, y_i, z_i) \) for \( i = 1, 2, \ldots, n \). The vector \( \overrightarrow{OA_i} \) can be represented as \( (x_i, y_i, z_i) \).

2. The magnitude of the vector \( \overrightarrow{OA_i} \) is given by:
   \[
   |\overrightarrow{OA_i}| = \sqrt{x_i^2 + y_i^2 + z_i^2}
   \]

3. The sum of the magnitudes of the vectors is:
   \[
   |\overrightarrow{OA_1}| + |\overrightarrow{OA_2}| + \cdots + |\overrightarrow{OA_n}| = \sum_{i=1}^n \sqrt{x_i^2 + y_i^2 + z_i^2}
   \]

4. The sum of the vectors \( \overrightarrow{OA_i} \) is:
   \[
   \overrightarrow{OA_1} + \overrightarrow{OA_2} + \cdots + \overrightarrow{OA_n} = \left( \sum_{i=1}^n x_i, \sum_{i=1}^n y_i, \sum_{i=1}^n z_i \right)
   \]

5. The magnitude of this resultant vector is:
   \[
   \left| \overrightarrow{OA_1} + \overrightarrow{OA_2} + \cdots + \overrightarrow{OA_n} \right| = \sqrt{\left( \sum_{i=1}^n x_i \right)^2 + \left( \sum_{i=1}^n y_i \right)^2 + \left( \sum_{i=1}^n z_i \right)^2}
   \]

6. Using the triangle inequality in three dimensions, we have:
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^n x_i \leq \sqrt{n \sum_{i=1}^n x_i^2}
   \]
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^n y_i \leq \sqrt{n \sum_{i=1}^n y_i^2}
   \]
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^n z_i \leq \sqrt{n \sum_{i=1}^n z_i^2}
   \]

7. Summing these inequalities, we get:
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^n x_i + \sum_{i=1}^n y_i + \sum_{i=1}^n z_i \leq \sqrt{n \sum_{i=1}^n x_i^2} + \sqrt{n \sum_{i=1}^n y_i^2} + \sqrt{n \sum_{i=1}^n z_i^2}
   \]

8. Using the inequality \( x + y + z \leq \sqrt{3(x^2 + y^2 + z^2)} \), we have:
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^n x_i + \sum_{i=1}^n y_i + \sum_{i=1}^n z_i \leq \sqrt{3 \left( \sum_{i=1}^n x_i^2 + \sum_{i=1}^n y_i^2 + \sum_{i=1}^n z_i^2 \right)}
   \]

9. Therefore, we can write:
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^n \sqrt{x_i^2 + y_i^2 + z_i^2} \leq \sqrt{3 \left( \sum_{i=1}^n x_i^2 + \sum_{i=1}^n y_i^2 + \sum_{i=1}^n z_i^2 \right)}
   \]

10. This implies:
   \[
   |\overrightarrow{OA_1}| + |\overrightarrow{OA_2}| + \cdots + |\overrightarrow{OA_n}| \leq \sqrt{3} \left| \overrightarrow{OA_1} + \overrightarrow{OA_2} + \cdots + \overrightarrow{OA_n} \right|
   \]

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
Point $O$ is the origin of a space. Points $A_1, A_2,\dots, A_n$ have nonnegative coordinates. Prove the following inequality:
$$|\overrightarrow{OA_1}|+|\overrightarrow {OA_2}|+\dots+|\overrightarrow {OA_n}|\leq \sqrt{3}|\overrightarrow {OA_1}+\overrightarrow{OA_2}+\dots+\overrightarrow{OA_n}|$$

[I]Proposed by A. Khrabrov[/i]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

$$|\overrightarrow{OA_1}|+|\overrightarrow {OA_2}|+\dots+|\overrightarrow {OA_n}|\leq \sqrt{3}|\overrightarrow {OA_1}+\overrightarrow{OA_2}+\dots+\overrightarrow{OA_n}|$$

[I]Proposed by A. Khrabrov[/i] -/
theorem inequalities_55933 (n : ‚Ñï) (A : Fin n ‚Üí EuclideanSpace ‚Ñù (Fin 3))
    (hA : ‚àÄ i, ‚àÄ j, (A i j) ‚â• 0) :
    ‚àë i, ‚ÄñA i‚Äñ ‚â§ sqrt 3 * ‚Äñ‚àë i, A i‚Äñ := by

soln_description:
1. **Identify the given conditions and the goal:**
   We need to find all monic nonconstant polynomials \( P \) with integer coefficients such that there exist positive integers \( a \) and \( m \) for which, for all positive integers \( n \equiv a \pmod{m} \), the expression 
   \[
   2022 \cdot \frac{(n+1)^{n+1} - n^n}{P(n)}
   \]
   is an integer.

2. **Check the given solution for specific polynomials:**
   The solution suggests that \( P(x) = x^2 + x + 1 \) and \( P(x) = (x^2 + x + 1)^2 \) work. We need to verify this.

3. **Verification for \( P(x) = x^2 + x + 1 \):**
   - Take \( a = 1 \) and \( m = 6 \).
   - We need to check if \( x^2 + x + 1 \mid (x+1)^{x+1} - x^x \) for \( x \equiv 1 \pmod{6} \).
   - For \( x \equiv 1 \pmod{6} \), let \( x = 6k + 1 \). Then,
     \[
     (6k+2)^{6k+2} - (6k+1)^{6k+1}
     \]
     We need to show that \( x^2 + x + 1 = (6k+1)^2 + (6k+1) + 1 = 36k^2 + 12k + 3 \) divides the above expression.

4. **Verification for \( P(x) = (x^2 + x + 1)^2 \):**
   - We need to show that if \( p^k \mid x^2 + x + 1 \), then \( p^{2k} \mid (x+1)^{x+1} - x^x \) for \( x \equiv 1 \pmod{6} \).
   - Let \( y = x + 6tp^k \) such that \( p^{2k} \mid y^2 + y + 1 \). Clearly, \( p^{2k} \mid (y+1)^{y+1} - y^y \).
   - We need to check:
     \[
     (x+1)^{x+1} - x^x \equiv (y+1-6tp^k)^{y+1-6tp^k} - (y-6tp^k)^{y-6tp^k} \pmod{p^{2k}}
     \]
     Using lifting the exponent, we can show that:
     \[
     \nu_p((y+1)^{6tp^k} - y^{6tp^k}) \ge k + \nu_p((y+1)^6 - y^6) \ge k + \nu_p(y^2 + y + 1) \ge 2k
     \]
     Thus, \( (y+1)^{y+1-6tp^k} \equiv y^{y-6tp^k} \pmod{p^{2k}} \).

5. **Verification for \( P(x) = (x^2 + x + 1)^3 \):**
   - Pick a large prime \( p > m \) such that \( p \mid x^2 + x + 1 \).
   - We need to show that \( p^3 \mid (x+1)^{x+1} - x^x \).
   - Consider all \( A \) such that \( p^3 \mid (x + Ap + 1)^{x + Ap + 1} - (x + Ap)^{x + Ap} \).
   - Expand and simplify modulo \( p^3 \):
     \[
     \left( \frac{x+1+Ap}{x+1} \right)^{x+1} (x+1+Ap)^{Ap} \equiv \left( \frac{x+Ap}{x} \right)^x (x+Ap)^{Ap} \pmod{p^3}
     \]
     This leads to a contradiction, showing that \( P(x) = (x^2 + x + 1)^3 \) fails.

Conclusion:
The only monic nonconstant polynomials \( P \) with integer coefficients that satisfy the given conditions are \( P(x) = x^2 + x + 1 \) and \( P(x) = (x^2 + x + 1)^2 \).

The final answer is \( \boxed{ P(x) = x^2 + x + 1 } \) and \( P(x) = (x^2 + x + 1)^2 \).
informal_statement:
Find all monic nonconstant polynomials $P$ with integer coefficients for which there exist positive integers $a$ and $m$ such that for all positive integers $n\equiv a\pmod m$, $P(n)$ is nonzero and $$2022\cdot\frac{(n+1)^{n+1} - n^n}{P(n)}$$ is an integer. 

[i]Jaedon Whyte, Luke Robitaille, and Pitchayut Saengrungkongka[/i]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find all monic nonconstant polynomials $P$ with integer coefficients for which there exist positive integers $a$ and $m$ such that for all positive integers $n\equiv a\pmod m$, $P(n)$ is nonzero and $$2022\cdot\frac{(n+1)^{n+1} - n^n}{P(n)}$$ is an integer. 

[i]Jaedon Whyte, Luke Robitaille, and Pitchayut Saengrungkongka[/i] -/
theorem number_theory_46783 {P : Polynomial ‚Ñ§} (hP : P.Monic)
    (hP1 : P.degree > 0) (hP2 : ‚àÉ a m : ‚Ñï, 0 < a ‚àß 0 < m ‚àß ‚àÄ n : ‚Ñï, n > 0 ‚Üí
    n ‚â° a [ZMOD m] ‚Üí P.eval (n : ‚Ñ§) ‚â† 0 ‚àß ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñ§, 2022 * ((n + 1) ^ (n + 1) - n ^ n) / P.eval (n : ‚Ñ§) = k) :
    P = X ^ 2 + X + 1 := by

soln_description: Given $f(x)=(x-2)^{3}+5(x-2)+13$, then the graph of $f(x)$ is symmetric about the point $(2,13)$, and $f(x)$ is monotonically increasing, so $f(x)+f(4-x)=26 \Rightarrow a+b=4$.
informal_statement: 6. Given the function $f(x)=x^{3}-6 x^{2}+17 x-5$, real numbers $a, b$ satisfy $f(a)=3, f(b)=23$, then $a+b=$
informal_proof:
We are given the function $f(x) = x^3 - 6x^2 + 17x - 5$ and two real numbers $a$ and $b$ such that $f(a) = 3$ and $f(b) = 23$.

From the definition of $f$, we can write specific equations for $a$ and $b$:
1.  For $a$, we have $f(a) = a^3 - 6a^2 + 17a - 5$. Since we are given $f(a) = 3$, this leads to the equation:
    $a^3 - 6a^2 + 17a - 5 = 3$
    By subtracting 3 from both sides, we get:
    $a^3 - 6a^2 + 17a - 8 = 0$  (Equation 1)

2.  For $b$, we have $f(b) = b^3 - 6b^2 + 17b - 5$. Since we are given $f(b) = 23$, this leads to the equation:
    $b^3 - 6b^2 + 17b - 5 = 23$
    By subtracting 23 from both sides, we get:
    $b^3 - 6b^2 + 17b - 28 = 0$  (Equation 2)

To solve this system of equations, we first analyze the structure of the polynomial $f(x)$. We can rewrite $f(x)$ by completing the cube around the term $(x-2)$:
$f(x) = (x^3 - 6x^2 + 12x - 8) + 5x - 5 - (-12x+8) = (x-2)^3 + 5x + 3$.
We can further express the remainder in terms of $(x-2)$:
$f(x) = (x-2)^3 + 5(x-2) + 10 + 3 = (x-2)^3 + 5(x-2) + 13$.

Now, let's use this form in our equations for $a$ and $b$:
- From $f(a)=3$, we have $(a-2)^3 + 5(a-2) + 13 = 3$, which simplifies to $(a-2)^3 + 5(a-2) + 10 = 0$.
- From $f(b)=23$, we have $(b-2)^3 + 5(b-2) + 13 = 23$, which simplifies to $(b-2)^3 + 5(b-2) - 10 = 0$.

Let $u = a - 2$ and $v = b - 2$. The two equations become:
(A) $u^3 + 5u + 10 = 0$
(B) $v^3 + 5v - 10 = 0$

Adding Equation (A) and Equation (B) gives:
$(u^3 + v^3) + (5u + 5v) = 0$
$u^3 + v^3 + 5(u+v) = 0$

We can factor the sum of cubes $u^3 + v^3$ as $(u+v)(u^2 - uv + v^2)$. Substituting this into the equation:
$(u+v)(u^2 - uv + v^2) + 5(u+v) = 0$
Factoring out the common term $(u+v)$:
$(u+v)(u^2 - uv + v^2 + 5) = 0$

This equation implies that either $u+v = 0$ or $u^2 - uv + v^2 + 5 = 0$.
Let's examine the second factor, $u^2 - uv + v^2 + 5$. We can rewrite this expression by completing the square:
$u^2 - uv + v^2 + 5 = \left(u - \frac{v}{2}\right)^2 - \frac{v^2}{4} + v^2 + 5 = \left(u - \frac{v}{2}\right)^2 + \frac{3}{4}v^2 + 5$.
Since squares of real numbers are non-negative, we have $(u - v/2)^2 \ge 0$ and $(3/4)v^2 \ge 0$. Therefore,
$\left(u - \frac{v}{2}\right)^2 + \frac{3}{4}v^2 + 5 \ge 5$.
This means the factor $u^2 - uv + v^2 + 5$ can never be zero.

Thus, we must have the first factor equal to zero:
$u + v = 0$

Substituting back $u = a-2$ and $v = b-2$:
$(a - 2) + (b - 2) = 0$
$a + b - 4 = 0$
$a + b = 4$

This completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6. Given the function $f(x)=x^{3}-6 x^{2}+17 x-5$, real numbers $a, b$ satisfy $f(a)=3, f(b)=23$, then $a+b=$ -/
theorem algebra_170801 (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (a b : ‚Ñù)
    (hf : ‚àÄ x, f x = x ^ 3 - 6 * x ^ 2 + 17 * x - 5)
    (ha : f a = 3) (hb : f b = 23) : a + b = 4 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_170801 (f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù) (a b : ‚Ñù)
    (hf : ‚àÄ x, f x = x ^ 3 - 6 * x ^ 2 + 17 * x - 5)
    (ha : f a = 3) (hb : f b = 23) : a + b = 4 := by
  have ha_eq : f a = a ^ 3 - 6 * a ^ 2 + 17 * a - 5 := hf a
  have hb_eq : f b = b ^ 3 - 6 * b ^ 2 + 17 * b - 5 := hf b
  rw [ha_eq] at ha
  rw [hb_eq] at hb
  have eq_a : a^3 - 6 * a^2 + 17 * a - 8 = 0 := by linarith
  have eq_b : b^3 - 6 * b^2 + 17 * b - 28 = 0 := by linarith
  nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (a + b - 4), sq_nonneg (a - 2), sq_nonneg (b - 2)]

soln_description:
Solution. We have

$$
\left(x^{2}+y^{2}-1\right)-(x+y+1)(x+y-1)=\left(x^{2}+y^{2}-1\right)-\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+2 x y-1\right)=-2 x y
$$

Since $x+y-1$ is a divisor of $x^{2}+y^{2}-1$ and also of $(x+y+1)(x+y-1)$, we see that $x+y-1$ is a divisor of $2 x y$. We know that $x+y+1$ is also a divisor of $2 x y$. But the greatest common divisor (gcd) of $x+y-1$ and $x+y+1$ is 1 or 2, since the difference between the two numbers is 2. Therefore, $2 x y$ is divisible by $(x+y-1)(x+y+1)$ (if the gcd is 1) or by $\frac{(x+y-1)(x+y+1)}{2}$ (if the gcd is 2). In both cases, $4 x y$ is divisible by $(x+y-1)(x+y+1)$, and thus for some $k \geq 1$ we have:

$$
4 x y=k(x+y-1)(x+y+1)=k\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+2 x y-1\right) \geq k(4 x y-1),
$$

where the last inequality holds because for all real numbers (and certainly for positive integers) $x$ and $y$, $x^{2}+y^{2} \geq 2 x y$.

If $k \geq 2$, then $4 x y \geq 2 \cdot(4 x y-1)$, so $4 x y \leq 2$. Contradiction, because $x$ and $y$ are positive and integers, so $4 x y \geq 4$. We conclude that $k=1$ and thus $4 x y=x^{2}+y^{2}+2 x y-1$. This simplifies to $x^{2}+y^{2}-1-2 x y=0$, which we can rewrite as $(x-y)^{2}=1$. Therefore, $x=y-1$ or $x=y+1$.

The possible pairs that satisfy this are thus $(x, x+1)$ with $x \geq 1$ and $(x, x-1)$ with $x \geq 2$. We check the first pair: $2 x+2$ must be a divisor of $2 x(x+1)$, and this is true; and $2 x$ must be a divisor of $x^{2}+(x+1)^{2}-1=2 x^{2}+2 x$, and this is also true. Similarly, the second pair also satisfies the conditions. Therefore, the solutions are: all pairs $(x, x+1)$ with $x \geq 1$ and all pairs $(x, x-1)$ with $x \geq 2$.

$$
x+y+1 \mid 2 x y \quad \text { and } \quad x+y-1 \mid x^{2}+y^{2}-1

soln_description:

$$
informal_statement:
4. Given a positive integer $n \geqslant 2$, real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ satisfy $a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}=0$. Define the set
$$
A=\left\{(i, j)|1 \leqslant i<j \leqslant n,| a_{i}-a_{j} \mid \geqslant 1\right\} .
$$

Prove: If $A$ is non-empty, then $\sum_{(i, j) \in A} a_{i} a_{j}<0$.

soln_description:
10.1.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { From } g(x)=f(x)+1-x \text { we get } f(x)=g(x)+x-1 . \\
\text { Then } g(x+5)+(x+5)-1 \geqslant g(x)+(x-1)+5 \text {, } \\
g(x+1)+(x+1)-1 \leqslant g(x)+(x-1)+1 . \\
\text { Therefore, } g(x+5) \geqslant g(x), g(x+1) \leqslant g(x) . \\
\therefore g(x) \leqslant g(x+5) \leqslant g(x+4) \leqslant g(x+3) \\
\quad \leqslant g(x+2) \leqslant g(x+1) \leqslant g(x) . \\
\therefore g(x+1)=g(x) .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $g(x)$ is a periodic function with a period of 1.
Given $g(1)=1$, hence $g(2002)=1$.

soln_description:
To find the smallest real number \( M = M(n, a) \) such that for any positive real numbers \( x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n \) with \( x_1 x_2 \cdots x_n = 1 \), the inequality
\[
\sum_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{a + S - x_i} \leq M
\]
holds, where \( S = \sum_{i=1}^n x_i \), we proceed as follows:

1. **Case Analysis for \( a < 1 \):**

   Consider \( x_1 = x_2 = \cdots = x_{n-1} = k \) and \( x_n = \frac{1}{k^{n-1}} \). As \( k \to 0 \), we have:
   \[
   S = (n-1)k + \frac{1}{k^{n-1}}
   \]
   Then,
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{a + S - x_i} = \frac{1}{a + (n-1)k} + \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} \frac{1}{a + (n-2)k + \frac{1}{k^{n-1}}}
   \]
   As \( k \to 0 \), the first term approaches \( \frac{1}{a} \) and the remaining terms approach 0. Therefore,
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{a + S - x_i} \to \frac{1}{a}
   \]
   Hence, for \( a < 1 \), \( M \geq \frac{1}{a} \).

2. **Case Analysis for \( a \geq 1 \):**

   Consider \( x_1 = x_2 = \cdots = x_n = 1 \). Then \( S = n \) and:
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{a + S - x_i} = \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{a + n - 1} = \frac{n}{a + n - 1}
   \]
   Hence, for \( a \geq 1 \), \( M \geq \frac{n}{a + n - 1} \).

3. **Combining the Results:**

   We need to find the smallest \( M \) that satisfies both cases. Therefore, we take the maximum of the two bounds:
   \[
   M = \max \left( \frac{1}{a}, \frac{n}{a + n - 1} \right)
   \]

4. **Verification:**

   To verify that this \( M \) works, we need to show that:
   \[
   \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{1}{a + S - x_i} \leq \max \left( \frac{1}{a}, \frac{n}{a + n - 1} \right)
   \]
   holds for all positive \( x_i \) with \( x_1 x_2 \cdots x_n = 1 \). This can be done by considering the behavior of the function and using inequalities such as AM-GM and Cauchy-Schwarz.

   For \( a < 1 \), the bound \( \frac{1}{a} \) is tight as shown in the first case. For \( a \geq 1 \), the bound \( \frac{n}{a + n - 1} \) is tight as shown in the second case.

The final answer is \( \boxed{ \max \left( \frac{1}{a}, \frac{n}{a + n - 1} \right) } \)
informal_statement:
Given integer $n\geq 2$ and positive real number $a$, find the smallest real number $M=M(n,a)$, such that for any positive real numbers $x_1,x_2,\cdots,x_n$ with $x_1 x_2\cdots x_n=1$, the following inequality holds:
\[\sum_{i=1}^n \frac {1}{a+S-x_i}\leq M\]
where $S=\sum_{i=1}^n x_i$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Given integer $n\geq 2$ and positive real number $a$, find the smallest real number $M=M(n,a)$, such that for any positive real numbers $x_1,x_2,\cdots,x_n$ with $x_1 x_2\cdots x_n=1$, the following inequality holds:
\[\sum_{i=1}^n \frac {1}{a+S-x_i}\leq M\]
where $S=\sum_{i=1}^n x_i$. -/
theorem inequalities_66444 (n : ‚Ñï) (hn : 2 ‚â§ n) (a : ‚Ñù) (ha : 0 < a) :
    IsLeast {M | ‚àÄ x : Fin n ‚Üí ‚Ñù, (‚àÄ i, 0 < x i) ‚àß (‚àè i, x i) = 1 ‚Üí
      ‚àë i, 1 / (a + ‚àë j, x j - x i) ‚â§ M} (max (1 / a) (n / (a + n - 1))) := by

soln_description: $\begin{array}{l}\text { 2. } \frac{2 n}{n+1} . \\ 1+\frac{1}{1+2}+\frac{1}{1+2+3}+\cdots+\frac{1}{1+2+3+\cdots+n} \\ =\frac{1}{\frac{1 \cdot 2}{2}}+\frac{1}{\frac{2 \cdot 3}{2}}+\frac{1}{\frac{3 \cdot 4}{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{\frac{n(n+1)}{2}} \\ =\frac{2}{1 \cdot 2}+\frac{2}{2 \cdot 3}+\frac{2}{3 \cdot 4}+\cdots+\frac{2}{n(n+1)} \\ =2\left(\frac{1}{1 \cdot 2}+\frac{1}{2 \cdot 3}+\frac{1}{3 \cdot 4}+\cdots+\frac{1}{n(n+1)}\right) \\ =2\left(1-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{4}+\cdots+\frac{1}{n}-\frac{1}{n+1}\right) \\ =2\left(\left(1-\frac{1}{n+1}\right)=\frac{2 n}{n+1} .\right.\end{array}$
informal_statement: $\begin{array}{l}\text { 2. } n \in N \text {, then } 1+\frac{1}{1+2}+\frac{1}{1+2+3}+\cdots+ \\ \frac{1}{1+2+3+\cdots+n}=\end{array}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset Real

/- $\begin{array}{l}\text { 2. } n \in N \text {, then } 1+\frac{1}{1+2}+\frac{1}{1+2+3}+\cdots+ \\ \frac{1}{1+2+3+\cdots+n}=\end{array}$ -/
theorem algebra_306196 (n : ‚Ñï) :
    ‚àë i ‚àà Icc 1 n, (1 / (‚àë j ‚àà Icc 1 i, j)) = 2 * n / (n + 1) := by

informal_statement:
196. Interesting square. Find a nine-digit integer of the form $\overline{a_{1} a_{2} a_{3} b_{1} b_{2} b_{3} a_{1} a_{2} a_{3}}$, which represents the product of the squares of four different prime numbers, and

$$
\overline{b_{1} b_{2} b_{3}}=2 \overline{\left(a_{1} a_{2} a_{3}\right)} \quad\left(a_{1} \neq 0\right)
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 196. Interesting square. Find a nine-digit integer of the form $\overline{a_{1} a_{2} a_{3} b_{1} b_{2} b_{3} a_{1} a_{2} a_{3}}$, which represents the product of the squares of four different prime numbers, and

$$
\overline{b_{1} b_{2} b_{3}}=2 \overline{\left(a_{1} a_{2} a_{3}\right)} \quad\left(a_{1} \neq 0\right)
$$ -/
theorem number_theory_270377 (n : ‚Ñï) (h‚ÇÄ : n > 0) (h‚ÇÅ : n < 10000000000)
    (h‚ÇÇ : ‚àÉ p q r s : ‚Ñï, p.Prime ‚àß q.Prime ‚àß r.Prime ‚àß s.Prime ‚àß p ‚â† q ‚àß p ‚â† r ‚àß p ‚â† s ‚àß q ‚â† r ‚àß q ‚â† s ‚àß r ‚â† s ‚àß
      n = p^2 * q^2 * r^2 * s^2) (h‚ÇÉ : (n / 1000) % 1000 = 2 * (n % 1000)) :
    n = 289578289 ‚à® n = 361722361 := by

soln_description:
The sum of the digits of the number 1 is equal to the sum of the digits of the number 1000; the remaining numbers will be divided into 499 pairs: $\{2,3\},\{4,5\}, \ldots$, $\{998,999\}$. In each pair, the sum of the digits of the odd number is 1 greater than the sum of the digits of the even number.

## Answer

The sum of the digits of the odd numbers is greater by 499.
informal_statement:
All natural numbers from 1 to 1000 inclusive are divided into two groups: even and odd.
In which of the groups is the sum of all digits used to write the numbers greater, and by how much?

#
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- All natural numbers from 1 to 1000 inclusive are divided into two groups: even and odd.
In which of the groups is the sum of all digits used to write the numbers greater, and by how much?

# -/
theorem number_theory_201842 :
    (‚àë n in (Finset.Icc 1 1000), (if Even n then (Nat.digits 10 n).sum else 0)) -
    (‚àë n in (Finset.Icc 1 1000), (if Odd n then (Nat.digits 10 n).sum else 0)) = 499 := by

soln_description: Solution. A person and a half, in two and a half days, eats three and a half loaves. This means that three people in 5 days eat $2 \cdot 2 \cdot 3.5=14$ loaves. One person in 1 day eats $\frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{1}{5} \cdot 14=\frac{14}{15}$ loaves. One person in 45 days eats $45 \cdot \frac{14}{15}=42$ loaves, and 100 people in 45 days eat $42 \cdot 100=4200$ loaves.
informal_statement: 2. A person and a half eats three and a half loaves in two and a half days. How many loaves will 100 people eat in 45 days?
informal_proof:
Let `x` be a real number such that `(1.5 * x) * 2.5 = 3.5`. We aim to show that `(100 * x) * 45 = 4200`.

First, we determine the value of `x` from the given equation. Using the associativity of multiplication, the equation `(1.5 * x) * 2.5 = 3.5` can be rewritten as:
`(1.5 * 2.5) * x = 3.5`

Calculating the product `1.5 * 2.5` gives `3.75`. So, we have:
`3.75 * x = 3.5`

Since `3.75` is non-zero, we can divide both sides by it to solve for `x`:
`x = 3.5 / 3.75`

To simplify this fraction, we can express the decimal numbers as fractions: `3.5 = 7/2` and `3.75 = 15/4`. Therefore:
`x = (7/2) / (15/4) = (7/2) * (4/15) = 28/30 = 14/15`

Now, we substitute this value of `x` into the expression `(100 * x) * 45`:
`(100 * (14/15)) * 45`

We can rearrange the terms to simplify the calculation:
`= 100 * (14/15) * 45`
`= 100 * 14 * (45/15)`

Since `45 / 15 = 3`, the expression becomes:
`= 100 * 14 * 3`
`= 100 * 42`
`= 4200`

Thus, we have demonstrated that `(100 * x) * 45 = 4200`, which completes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. A person and a half eats three and a half loaves in two and a half days. How many loaves will 100 people eat in 45 days? -/
theorem algebra_242421 (x : ‚Ñù) (hx : x ‚â† 0) (h : (1.5 * x) * 2.5 = 3.5) :
    (100 * x) * 45 = 4200 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_242421 (x : ‚Ñù) (hx : x ‚â† 0) (h : (1.5 * x) * 2.5 = 3.5) :
    (100 * x) * 45 = 4200 := by
  have hx_eq : x = 3.5 / (1.5 * 2.5 : ‚Ñù) := by
    field_simp at h ‚ä¢
    linarith
  rw [hx_eq]
  norm_num

soln_description:
Solution. Let $(x, y), x>y$ be a pair of prime numbers. From the condition of the problem, it follows that $x^{2}-y^{2}=120$, i.e., $\quad(x-y)(x+y)=120$. Obviously, $x-y+x+y=2 x$ is an even number, so both factors must have the same parity. Since the product of two odd numbers is an odd number, we conclude that both factors must be even. Therefore, the following cases are possible:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x+y=60 \\
x-y=2
\end{array}, \quad\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x+y=30 \\
x-y=4
\end{array}, \quad\left\{\begin{array} { l } 
{ x + y = 2 0 } \\
{ x - y = 6 }
\end{array} \text { and } \left\{\begin{array}{l}
x+y=12 \\
x-y=10
\end{array} .\right.\right.\right.\right.
$$

The solutions to the first three systems are the required ordered pairs of prime numbers $(x, y)$, i.e., $(31,29),(17,13)$ and $(13,7)$, while the last system does not provide a solution, as it yields $x=11$ and $y=1$, and 1 is not a prime number.
informal_statement: Task 1. Determine all pairs of prime numbers whose difference of squares is equal to 120.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Task 1. Determine all pairs of prime numbers whose difference of squares is equal to 120. -/
theorem number_theory_237448 (p q : ‚Ñï) (hp : p.Prime) (hq : q.Prime)
    (h : |(p ^ 2 : ‚Ñ§) - q ^ 2| = 120) :
    (p, q) = (31, 29) ‚à® (p, q) = (17, 13) ‚à® (p, q) = (13, 7) := by

informal_statement:
Let $a, b, c > 0$ and $abc = 1$. Prove the inequality:
\[
\frac{1 + ab^2}{c^3} + \frac{1 + bc^2}{a^3} + \frac{1 + ca^2}{b^3} \geq \frac{18}{a^3 + b^3 + c^3}.
\]

import Mathlib

/- Let $a, b, c > 0$ and $abc = 1$. Prove the inequality:
\[
\frac{1 + ab^2}{c^3} + \frac{1 + bc^2}{a^3} + \frac{1 + ca^2}{b^3} \geq \frac{18}{a^3 + b^3 + c^3}.
\] -/
theorem inequalities_4389
(a b c : ‚Ñù)
(h : 0 < a ‚àß 0 < b ‚àß 0 < c)
(h1 : a * b * c = 1)
: 18 / (a ^ 3 + b ^ 3 + c ^ 3) ‚â§ (1 + a * b ^ 2) / c ^ 3 + (1 + b * c ^ 2) / a ^ 3 + (1 + c * a ^ 2) / b ^ 3 := by

soln_description: 2. $\mathrm{C}$ Because an even function is symmetric about the $y$-axis. If the graph of the function $y=f(x)$ is symmetric about the line $x=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}$, then $f\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}-x\right)=$ $f\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}+x\right)$, which means $f(x+\sqrt{2})=f\left[\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}+\left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}+x\right)\right]=f(-x)=f(x)$, hence the function is a periodic function with a period of $\sqrt{2}$. The correct choice is $\mathrm{C}$.
informal_statement:
2. (2007 Zhejiang Province High School Mathematics Competition B Paper) Let the non-constant function \( f(x) (x \in \mathbf{R}) \) be an even function, and its graph is symmetric about the line \( x = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \). Then the function is
A. A non-periodic function
B. A periodic function with a period of \( \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \)
C. A periodic function with a period of \( \sqrt{2} \)
D. A periodic function with a period of 2
informal_proof:
Let \(x\) be an arbitrary real number. We are given that for any real number \(y\), \(f(y - \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}) = f(y + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2})\). Our goal is to show that \(f(x - \sqrt{2}) = f(x + \sqrt{2})\).

First, we will establish that \(f(x) = f(x + \sqrt{2})\). Let's apply the given identity by substituting \(y = x + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\).
The left-hand side of the identity becomes:
\[ f\left(\left(x + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right) - \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right) = f(x) \]
The right-hand side of the identity becomes:
\[ f\left(\left(x + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right) + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right) = f(x + \sqrt{2}) \]
Thus, by substituting \(y = x + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\) into the given identity, we obtain the equality:
\[ f(x) = f(x + \sqrt{2}) \]

Next, we will establish that \(f(x - \sqrt{2}) = f(x)\). We apply the given identity again, this time substituting \(y = x - \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\).
The left-hand side of the identity becomes:
\[ f\left(\left(x - \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right) - \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right) = f(x - \sqrt{2}) \]
The right-hand side of the identity becomes:
\[ f\left(\left(x - \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right) + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right) = f(x) \]
This substitution yields our second equality:
\[ f(x - \sqrt{2}) = f(x) \]

Now, we have the following two equalities:
1. \(f(x - \sqrt{2}) = f(x)\)
2. \(f(x) = f(x + \sqrt{2})\)

By the transitivity of equality, we can combine these results to conclude that:
\[ f(x - \sqrt{2}) = f(x + \sqrt{2}) \]
Since \(x\) was an arbitrary real number, this equality holds for all \(x \in \mathbb{R}\).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 2. (2007 Zhejiang Province High School Mathematics Competition B Paper) Let the non-constant function \( f(x) (x \in \mathbf{R}) \) be an even function, and its graph is symmetric about the line \( x = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \). Then the function is
A. A non-periodic function
B. A periodic function with a period of \( \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \)
C. A periodic function with a period of \( \sqrt{2} \)
D. A periodic function with a period of 2 -/
theorem algebra_169883 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (hf : Even f)
  (h : ‚àÄ x, f (x - sqrt 2 / 2) = f (x + sqrt 2 / 2)) :
  ‚àÄ x, f (x - sqrt 2) = f (x + sqrt 2) :=
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

theorem algebra_169883 {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} (hf : Even f)
  (h : ‚àÄ x, f (x - sqrt 2 / 2) = f (x + sqrt 2 / 2)) :
  ‚àÄ x, f (x - sqrt 2) = f (x + sqrt 2) := by
  intro x
  have h1 : f x = f (x + sqrt 2) := by
    specialize h (x + sqrt 2 / 2)
    have h_left : (x + sqrt 2 / 2) - sqrt 2 / 2 = x := by ring
    have h_right : (x + sqrt 2 / 2) + sqrt 2 / 2 = x + sqrt 2 := by ring
    rw [h_left] at h
    rw [h_right] at h
    simpa using h
  have h2 : f (x - sqrt 2) = f x := by
    specialize h (x - sqrt 2 / 2)
    have h_left : (x - sqrt 2 / 2) - sqrt 2 / 2 = x - sqrt 2 := by ring
    have h_right : (x - sqrt 2 / 2) + sqrt 2 / 2 = x := by ring
    rw [h_left] at h
    rw [h_right] at h
    simpa using h
  linarith [h1, h2]

soln_description:
$=1.0$.
Since $x=y+\sqrt{2}$, we have,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
(x-y)^{2}=2, (x+y)^{2}-4 x y=2, \\
2 x y=\frac{1}{2}(x+y)^{2}-1 .
\end{array}
$$

Substituting this into $2 x y+2 \sqrt{2} z^{2}+1=0$ yields

$$

/- 1. Real numbers $x, y, z$ satisfy $x=y+\sqrt{2}, 2 x y+$ $2 \sqrt{2} z^{2}+1=0$. Then the value of $x+y+z$ is $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_324174 {x y z : ‚Ñù} (h‚ÇÅ : x = y + Real.sqrt 2) (h‚ÇÇ : 2 * x * y + 2 * Real.sqrt 2 * z^2 + 1 = 0) :
    x + y + z = 1 := by

informal_statement: 2. From points $A$ and $B$, which are 300 km apart, two cars set off simultaneously. The speed of the car that left from $A$ is 40 km/h. Determine the speed of the second car, given that after two hours the distance between them was 100 km.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. From points $A$ and $B$, which are 300 km apart, two cars set off simultaneously. The speed of the car that left from $A$ is 40 km/h. Determine the speed of the second car, given that after two hours the distance between them was 100 km. -/
theorem algebra_282453 (v : ‚Ñù) (h : v > 0) (h' : 2 * v + 2 * 40 = 300 - 100) :
    v = 140 := by

soln_description:
7. (B)

In the set $M$, $|x y|=1$ is equivalent to $x y=1$ or $x y=-1$ but $x>0$, hence it represents the branches of the hyperbolic function graph in the I and IV quadrants.
In the set $N$, from $\operatorname{arctg} x+\operatorname{arcctg} y=\pi$ we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
x & =\operatorname{tg}(\operatorname{arctg} x)=\operatorname{tg}(\pi-\operatorname{arcctg} y) \\
& =-\operatorname{tg}(\operatorname{arcctg} y)=-\frac{1}{\operatorname{ctg}(\operatorname{arcctg} y)}=-\frac{1}{y} .
\end{aligned}
$$

That is, $x y=-1$ which represents the two branches of the hyperbolic function curve in the II and III quadrants.

Since $-\frac{\pi}{2}<\operatorname{arctg} x<\frac{\pi}{2}$ and $0<\operatorname{arcctg} y<\pi$, when $x>0$, $0<\operatorname{arcctg} y<\frac{\pi}{2}$, and when $x<0$, $\frac{\pi}{2}<\operatorname{arcctg} y<\pi$.
Thus, the set $\{ (x, y) \mid x y=-1, x>0 \}$ is the branch of the hyperbolic function curve $x y=-1$ in the IV quadrant, and the set $\{ (x, y) \mid x y=-1, x<0 \}$ is the branch of the hyperbolic function curve $x y=-1$ in the II quadrant.
It is known that $N \subset M \quad \therefore M \cup N=M$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 7. Let $M=\{(x, y):|x y|=1, x>0\}$, $N=\{(x, y): \operatorname{arctg} x+\operatorname{arcctg} y=\pi\}$, then
(A) $M \cup N=\{(x, y):|x y|=1\}$;
(B) $M \cup N=M$;
(C) $M \cup N=N$;
(D) $M \cup N=\{(x, y):|x y|=1$, and $x, y$ are not both negative $\}$. -/
theorem algebra_133786 {x y : ‚Ñù} (hx : x > 0) :
    (x, y) ‚àà {(x, y) | abs (x * y) = 1 ‚àß x > 0} ‚à™
    {(x, y) | arctan x + arctan (1 / y) = œÄ} ‚Üî
    (x, y) ‚àà {(x, y) | abs (x * y) = 1 ‚àß x > 0} := by

soln_description:
## First solution.

For $m=1$ the observed equation is linear $(-2 x+2=0)$, and its solution $x=1$ is not negative.

For $m \neq 1$, the discriminant of the equation

$$
D=4 m^{2}-4 \cdot 2 \cdot(m-1)=4 m^{2}-8 m+8=(2 m-2)^{2}+4
$$

is positive, so this quadratic equation always has two real solutions, $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$.

The conditions $x_{1} \geqslant 0, x_{2} \geqslant 0$ are satisfied if and only if $x_{1}+x_{2} \geqslant 0$ and $x_{1} x_{2} \geqslant 0$.

1 point

By applying Vieta's formulas, we get

$$
x_{1}+x_{2}=\frac{2 m}{m-1}, \quad x_{1} x_{2}=\frac{2}{m-1}
$$

Thus, it must hold that $\frac{2 m}{m-1} \geqslant 0, \frac{2}{m-1} \geqslant 0$.

From the first inequality, we get $m \in\langle-\infty, 0] \cup\langle 1, \infty\rangle$, and from the second $m>1$.

Finally, the initial equation has no negative solutions for $m \geqslant 1$.
informal_statement:
## Task A-2.1. (4 points)

For which values of the real parameter $m$ does the equation

$$
(m-1) x^{2}-2 m x+2=0
$$

have no negative real solutions?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Task A-2.1. (4 points)

For which values of the real parameter $m$ does the equation

$$
(m-1) x^{2}-2 m x+2=0
$$

have no negative real solutions? -/
theorem algebra_206884 (m : ‚Ñù) :
    ¬¨‚àÉ x : ‚Ñù, x < 0 ‚àß (m-1)*x^2-2*m*x+2=0 ‚Üî m ‚â• 1 := by

soln_description:
1. We start with the given quartic equation:
   \[
   r^4z^4 + (10r^6 - 2r^2)z^2 - 16r^5z + (9r^8 + 10r^4 + 1) = 0
   \]

2. We factor the quartic polynomial. Notice that the constant term can be factored as:
   \[
   9r^8 + 10r^4 + 1 = (9r^4 + 1)(r^4 + 1)
   \]

3. Assume the quartic can be factored into two quadratics:
   \[
   (r^2z^2 + az + b)(r^2z^2 + cz + d)
   \]

4. By comparing coefficients, we find:
   \[
   r^4z^4 + (a+c)r^2z^3 + (ac + b + d)z^2 + (ad + bc)z + bd = r^4z^4 + (10r^6 - 2r^2)z^2 - 16r^5z + (9r^8 + 10r^4 + 1)
   \]

5. From the constant term, we have:
   \[
   bd = 9r^8 + 10r^4 + 1
   \]

6. From the coefficient of \(z\), we have:
   \[
   ad + bc = -16r^5
   \]

7. From the coefficient of \(z^2\), we have:
   \[
   ac + b + d = 10r^6 - 2r^2
   \]

8. We can factor the quartic as:
   \[
   (r^2z^2 + 2rz + (9r^4 + 1))(r^2z^2 - 2rz + (r^4 + 1))
   \]

9. Using the quadratic formula on each quadratic factor, we find the roots:
   \[
   r^2z^2 + 2rz + (9r^4 + 1) = 0 \implies z = \frac{-2r \pm \sqrt{4r^2 - 4r^2(9r^4 + 1)}}{2r^2} = \frac{-2r \pm 2r\sqrt{9r^4}}{2r^2} = \frac{-1 \pm 3ri}{r}
   \]
   \[
   r^2z^2 - 2rz + (r^4 + 1) = 0 \implies z = \frac{2r \pm \sqrt{4r^2 - 4r^2(r^4 + 1)}}{2r^2} = \frac{2r \pm 2r\sqrt{r^4}}{2r^2} = \frac{1 \pm ri}{r}
   \]

10. The roots are:
    \[
    z_1 = \frac{-1 + 3ri}{r}, \quad z_2 = \frac{-1 - 3ri}{r}, \quad z_3 = \frac{1 + ri}{r}, \quad z_4 = \frac{1 - ri}{r}
    \]

11. Plotting these points on the complex plane, we have:
    \[
    z_1 = -\frac{1}{r} + 3i, \quad z_2 = -\frac{1}{r} - 3i, \quad z_3 = \frac{1}{r} + i, \quad z_4 = \frac{1}{r} - i
    \]

12. These points form an isosceles trapezoid with height \(\frac{2}{r}\) and bases \(2ri\) and \(6ri\).

13. The area of the trapezoid is given by:
    \[
    \text{Area} = \frac{1}{2} \times (\text{Base}_1 + \text{Base}_2) \times \text{Height} = \frac{1}{2} \times (2r + 6r) \times \frac{2}{r} = \frac{1}{2} \times 8r \times \frac{2}{r} = 8
    \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{8}\).
informal_statement:
Let $r$ be a nonzero real number. The values of $z$ which satisfy the equation \[ r^4z^4 + (10r^6-2r^2)z^2-16r^5z+(9r^8+10r^4+1) = 0  \] are plotted on the complex plane (i.e. using the real part of each root as the x-coordinate
and the imaginary part as the y-coordinate). Show that the area of the convex quadrilateral with these points as vertices is independent of $r$, and find this area.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $r$ be a nonzero real number. The values of $z$ which satisfy the equation \[ r^4z^4 + (10r^6-2r^2)z^2-16r^5z+(9r^8+10r^4+1) = 0  \] are plotted on the complex plane (i.e. using the real part of each root as the x-coordinate
and the imaginary part as the y-coordinate). Show that the area of the convex quadrilateral with these points as vertices is independent of $r$, and find this area. -/
theorem algebra_25618 (r : ‚Ñù) (hr : r ‚â† 0) :
    ‚àÉ A B C D : ‚ÑÇ, A ‚â† B ‚àß A ‚â† C ‚àß A ‚â† D ‚àß B ‚â† C ‚àß B ‚â† D ‚àß C ‚â† D ‚àß
      r ^ 4 * A ^ 4 + (10 * r ^ 6 - 2 * r ^ 2) * A ^ 2 - 16 * r ^ 5 * A +
        (9 * r ^ 8 + 10 * r ^ 4 + 1) = 0 ‚àß
      r ^ 4 * B ^ 4 + (10 * r ^ 6 - 2 * r ^ 2) * B ^ 2 - 16 * r ^ 5 * B +
        (9 * r ^ 8 + 10 * r ^ 4 + 1) = 0 ‚àß
      r ^ 4 * C ^ 4 + (10 * r ^ 6 - 2 * r ^ 2) * C ^ 2 - 16 * r ^ 5 * C +
        (9 * r ^ 8 + 10 * r ^ 4 + 1) = 0 ‚àß
      r ^ 4 * D ^ 4 + (10 * r ^ 6 - 2 * r ^ 2) * D ^ 2 - 16 * r ^ 5 * D +
        (9 * r ^ 8 + 10 * r ^ 4 + 1) = 0 ‚àß
      (MeasureTheory.volume (convexHull ‚Ñù {A, B, C, D})).toReal = 8 := by

soln_description:
Prove that the given relation is
$$(a-b)(2a+2b+1)=b^2$$

The first point of the argument is to prove that the integers $a-b$ and $2a+2b+1$ are coprime. Let $d=(a-b, 2a+2b+1)$. If $d>1$, then $d$ has a prime factor $p$, and thus from (1) we know $p \mid b^2$. Since $p$ is a prime, it follows that $p \mid b$. Combining this with $p \mid (a-b)$, we get $p \mid a$. Then, from $p \mid (2a+2b+1)$, we derive $p \mid 1$, which is impossible. Therefore, $d=1$. Since the right-hand side of (1) is $b^2$, a perfect square, it follows that $|a-b|$ and $|2a+2b+1|$ are both perfect squares (see (8) in Unit 2).

Now, we prove that $a-b \geqslant 0$. From (1), we know $2a+2b+1 \geqslant 0$, so $a-b$ and $2a+2b+1$ are both perfect squares.

Assume there are integers $a, b$ satisfying the equation in the problem, but $a-b < 0$. Let $a-b = -r^2$ where $r > 0$; combining this with (1) we get $r \mid b$, and from $b-a = r^2$ we get $r \mid a$. Let $b = b_1 r$ and $a = a_1 r$, substituting into the equation in the problem (note $r > 0$ and $b_1 = a_1 + r$), we get
$$a_1^2 + 6a_1 r + 3r^2 + 1 = 0$$

To prove that the above equation cannot hold, we can use the following method:
Consider (2) as a quadratic equation in $a_1$, and solve it using the quadratic formula:
$$a_1 = -3r \pm \sqrt{6r^2 - 1}$$

Since $a_1$ is an integer, it follows from the above equation that $6r^2 - 1$ must be a perfect square. However, it is easy to see that the remainder when a perfect square is divided by 3 can only be 0 or 1; but the remainder when $6r^2 - 1$ is divided by 3 is 2, leading to a contradiction.

Or more directly: Since $a_1^2$ leaves a remainder of 0 or 1 when divided by 3, the left-hand side of (2) leaves a remainder of 1 or 2 when divided by 3; but the right-hand side of (2) is 0, divisible by 3. This is a contradiction. Therefore, (2) does not hold for any integers $a_1$ and $r$, so we must have $a-b \geqslant 0$, which proves the conclusion of the problem.
informal_statement: Example 4 Proof: If integers $a, b$ satisfy $2a^2 + a = 3b^2 + b$, then $a - b$ and $2a + 2b + 1$ are both perfect squares.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 4 Proof: If integers $a, b$ satisfy $2a^2 + a = 3b^2 + b$, then $a - b$ and $2a + 2b + 1$ are both perfect squares. -/
theorem number_theory_8037 {a b : ‚Ñ§} (h : 2*a^2 + a = 3*b^2 + b) :
    ‚àÉ m, m^2 = a - b ‚àß ‚àÉ n, n^2 = 2*a + 2*b + 1 := by

soln_description:
Solution. In this case, the L'H√¥pital-Bernoulli rule needs to be applied twice, as the ratio of the first derivatives again represents an indeterminate form of $\frac{0}{0}$.

Indeed,

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin x e^{2 x}-x}{5 x^{2}+x^{3}}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\left(\sin x e^{2 x}-x\right)^{\prime}}{\left(5 x^{2}+x^{3}\right)^{\prime}}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\cos x e^{2 x}+2 \sin x e^{2 x}-1}{10 x+3 x^{2}}
$$

As $x \rightarrow 0$, we again obtain an indeterminate form of $\frac{0}{0}$. Applying the L'H√¥pital-Bernoulli rule once more, we find

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\cos x e^{2 x}+2 \sin x e^{2 x}-1}{10 x+3 x^{2}}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\left(\cos x e^{2 x}+2 \sin x e^{2 x}-1\right)^{\prime}}{\left(10 x+3 x^{2}\right)^{\prime}}=
$$

$$
=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-\sin x e^{2 x}+4 \cos x e^{2 x}+4 \sin x e^{2 x}}{10+6 x}=\frac{4}{10}=\frac{2}{5}
$$
informal_statement: Example 2. Find $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin x e^{2 x}-x}{5 x^{2}+x^{3}}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Real Complex TopologicalSpace Finset
open scoped BigOperators

/- Example 2. Find $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin x e^{2 x}-x}{5 x^{2}+x^{3}}$. -/
theorem calculus_162334 :
  Tendsto (Œª x => (Real.sin x * Real.exp (2 * x) - x) / (5 * x^2 + x^3)) (ùìù[‚â†] 0) (ùìù (2 / 5)) :=

soln_description:
$\triangle$ Out of 17 natural numbers, 8 are even:

$$
2,4,6,8,10,12,14,16 \text{, }
$$

the remaining 9 are odd. The sum of all these even numbers is even (property 3), the sum of the odd numbers is odd (property 5). Therefore, the sum of all 17 numbers is odd as it is the sum of an even and an odd number (property 4).

Answer: odd.
informal_statement: 83. Even or odd sum of all natural numbers from 1 to 17?
informal_proof:
We want to determine if the sum of all natural numbers from 1 to 17 is odd. Let S be this sum:
$$ S = \sum_{n=1}^{17} n = 1 + 2 + 3 + \dots + 17 $$

We can compute the value of this sum directly. Using the formula for the sum of the first $k$ positive integers, which is $\frac{k(k+1)}{2}$, we set $k=17$:
$$ S = \frac{17(17+1)}{2} = \frac{17 \times 18}{2} = 17 \times 9 $$
Performing the multiplication, we find:
$$ S = 153 $$

Now, we must check if the number 153 is odd. An integer $m$ is defined as odd if there exists an integer $k$ such that $m = 2k + 1$. We can express 153 in this form:
$$ 153 = 2 \times 76 + 1 $$
Since we have found such an integer $k=76$, the number 153 is odd by definition.

Therefore, the sum of all natural numbers from 1 to 17 is odd.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 83. Even or odd sum of all natural numbers from 1 to 17? -/
theorem number_theory_111701 : Odd (‚àë n in Finset.Icc 1 17, n) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_111701 : Odd (‚àë n in Finset.Icc 1 17, n) := by 
  native_decide

10. Let $\sqrt{u}=a \cdot \sqrt{\sin \theta}, \sqrt{v}=b \cdot \sqrt{\cos \theta}$, then the condition transforms to: $\frac{u^{2}}{a^{4}}+\frac{v^{2}}{b^{4}}=1, u$ „ÄÅ $v \geqslant 0$, using the Cauchy inequality,
$$\begin{aligned}
y & =\sqrt{u}+\sqrt{v} \leqslant \sqrt{\left(\frac{u}{a^{\frac{4}{3}}}+\frac{v}{b^{\frac{4}{3}}}\right)\left(a^{\frac{4}{3}}+b^{\frac{4}{3}}\right)} \\
& \leqslant \sqrt{\sqrt{\left(\frac{u^{2}}{a^{4}}+\frac{v^{2}}{b^{4}}\right)\left(a^{\frac{4}{3}}+b^{\frac{4}{3}}\right)} \cdot\left(a^{\frac{4}{3}}+b^{\frac{4}{3}}\right)} \\
& =\left(a^{\frac{4}{3}}+b^{\frac{4}{3}}\right)^{\frac{1}{4}}
\end{aligned}$$

It is easy to find the condition for equality to hold.

soln_description:
$=7 . \mid-1, \sqrt{7}\}$.
Since the solution to the inequality $\frac{1}{8}<2^{x}<8$ is $-3<x<3$, therefore, $B=(-3,3)$.
When $x \in A \cap B$, $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x^{2}-2[x]=3, \\ -3<x<3 .\end{array}\right.$
Thus, $[x]$ can only take the values $-3,-2,-1,0,1,2$.
If $[x] \leqslant-2$, then $x^{2}=3+2[x]<0$, which has no real solutions;

If $[x]=-1$, then $x^{2}=1$, solving gives $x=-1$; if $[x]=0$, then $x^{2}=3$, which has no valid solutions; if $[x]=1$, then $x^{2}=5$, which has no valid solutions; if $[x]=2$, then $x^{2}=7$, solving gives $x=\sqrt{7}$.
Therefore, $A \cap B=\{-1, \sqrt{7}\}$.
informal_statement:

B=\left\{x \left\lvert\, \frac{1}{8}<2^{x}<8\right.\right\} .
\end{array}
$$

Then $A \cap B=$ $\qquad$

/- 7. Let $[x]$ denote the greatest integer not greater than $x$, and the sets

B=\left\{x \left\lvert\, \frac{1}{8}<2^{x}<8\right.\right\} .
\end{array}
$$

Then $A \cap B=$ $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_322117 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : x^2 - 2 * ‚åäx‚åã = 3) :
    x ‚àà Ioo (-1) (Real.sqrt 7) := by

import Mathlib

/- 7. Let $(x+1)^{2017}=a_{0} x^{2017}+a_{1} x^{2016}+a_{2} x^{2015}+\cdots+a_{2016} x+a_{2017}$, then the value of $a_{1}+a_{5}+a_{9}+\cdots+a_{2017}$ is $\qquad$ . -/
